Diagnosis: Acute hepatitis B infection causing marked hepatocellular injury. Rationale: The patient has reproducibly positive HBsAg on multiple platforms including confirmatory neutralization and positive IgM anti-HBc, which are diagnostic of acute HBV infection. Alternative causes have been extensively evaluated and are unlikely: comprehensive viral testing (HAV, HCV, HEV, HDV, EBV, CMV, HSV, HIV) and autoimmune serologies are negative; toxicology and acetaminophen levels are normal; RUQ ultrasound is normal. Undetectable HBV DNA on multiple ultrasensitive PCR assays is atypical but can occur early in infection or when immune-mediated clearance produces very low/brief viremia below assay limits; sequencing showed no escape mutations and HBsAg positivity was confirmed, making assay interference unlikely. Clinical status and labs show preserved synthetic function (normal PT/INR, albumin), normal bilirubin, and no encephalopathy, so this is not fulminant hepatic failure at present.

Management and follow-up plan (what was or would be done next):
- Supportive care and close monitoring: continue serial hepatic panel and PT/INR at least every 12–24 hours until trend is clear and then less frequently as improving; monitor for development of jaundice, coagulopathy (INR >1.5), or encephalopathy.
- Repeat HBV DNA testing periodically (in 48–72 hrs and if clinical worsening) to detect rising viremia; document HBsAg clearance vs persistence. If HBV DNA becomes detectable or if clinical course progresses to severe/fulminant hepatitis (INR >1.5, encephalopathy, rising bilirubin), initiate nucleos(t)ide analogue therapy (tenofovir or entecavir) promptly and involve hepatology/transplant as needed.
- Public health action: report acute HBV to public health authorities and arrange evaluation/vaccination/immunoprophylaxis (HBIG) for close contacts as indicated; counsel patient on transmission precautions (no blood donation, safe sex, avoid sharing needles, avoid alcohol and hepatotoxins).
- Arrange follow-up HBsAg at 6 months to document clearance vs chronic infection; counsel regarding vaccination status (patient likely nonimmune prior to this infection).

Remaining uncertainties I would still clarify with additional rounds if possible: serial trends in ALT/AST, bilirubin, and INR over the next 48–72 hours and repeat HBV DNA to confirm whether viremia remains undetectable or becomes detectable; monitor clinical signs for encephalopathy. If these remain stable or improve, continue supportive care without antiviral therapy; if worsen, escalate to antiviral therapy and hepatology referral.
